notes: This module uses Rep as the primary resource. Implementation uses hp effects so the existing HUD bar updates.
System lines use Whisper/Omen/Note and Immediate System Echo.
Romance overlap is allowed and can increase reputation risk.

sections.text:
The fluorescent lights make everything feel too bright and not bright enough at the same time.

Your badge still looks new. Your hands don’t.

First day as an intern. First day where every mistake has a name.

Across the nurse’s station, the attending you’ve heard whispered about—Dr. Celeste Marlowe—turns a page in a chart like she’s turning the whole room.

A nurse with sharp eyes and a softer voice, Kimberly, gives you a once-over.

And at the far end, behind glass and policy, an administrator watches the floor like it’s a chessboard: Avery Sloan.
sections.system: Note: This story uses Rep. The HUD bar reflects Rep changes. Your starting Rep is steady.

choices.label: Check your badge, breathe, and walk up to Dr. Marlowe
Ask Nurse Kimberly what you should know before you mess up
Introduce yourself to Avery in administration—make a good impression early

sections.text:
Dr. Marlowe doesn’t look up immediately.

“That chart,” she says, still reading. “Tell me what you see. Don’t guess. Don’t perform. See.”

She finally meets your eyes. There’s a kind of warmth there—quiet, expensive.

Then she looks away again like she didn’t just pull your spine straighter.
sections.system: Whisper: With Marlowe, competence is intimacy.

choices.label: Answer carefully—stick to what’s on the page
Take a risk and suggest a diagnosis
Admit you need guidance and ask for one thing to focus on today

sections.text:
Kimberly leans close enough that her perfume is barely there—clean, like soap and something brave.

“Rule one,” she says. “If you don’t know, say you don’t know. Rule two: don’t let anyone bully you into lying.”

She taps your chart. “And rule three… you’re allowed to be human. Just not careless.”
sections.system: Whisper: Kimberly doesn’t flirt. She protects.

choices.label: Thank her and ask her to keep you honest today
Ask how she survives the shift without breaking
Play it cool—pretend you already knew that

sections.text:
Avery Sloan’s office is glass and quiet.

They don’t smile right away. They measure.

“Intern,” Avery says. “Welcome to the machine.”

It sounds cruel until you realize it’s honest.

“And machines,” they add, “break when people pretend they don’t.”
sections.system: Whisper: Avery respects truth—especially inconvenient truth.

choices.label: Say you want to be excellent—not perfect
Ask what gets interns in trouble fastest
Deflect with charm and humor

sections.text:
You describe what’s there—vitals, meds, timing. Nothing extra.

Dr. Marlowe nods once.

“Good,” she says. “Now tell me what’s missing.”

That tiny approval hits harder than any flirtation.
sections.system: Note: Your professionalism improves your standing. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Ask for the latest labs
Ask Kimberly if she’s seen anything the chart won’t show
Ask Marlowe if she always teaches like this

sections.text:
You suggest a diagnosis.

Silence.

Dr. Marlowe’s expression stays controlled, but the room gets colder by a degree.

“Back it up,” she says. “Or retract it.”
sections.system: Omen: In this hospital, confidence without evidence costs you. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Retract it—own the mistake
Try to justify it anyway
Ask to review the patient chart again

sections.text:
“One thing,” you say. “What should I get right today?”

Marlowe studies you, then gives a small smile.

“Timing,” she says. “Medicine is timing. Love is timing. Disaster is timing.”

Then she turns away like she didn’t just drop a match in your chest.
sections.system: Whisper: She just told you how to survive her.

choices.label: Follow her lead to the next patient
Ask Kimberly what Marlowe meant by that
Pretend you didn’t feel that and focus on work

sections.text:
Kimberly’s eyes soften.

“Okay,” she says. “But if you start lying to yourself, I’ll call you on it.”

She hands you a pager like it’s a dare.

“Congratulations,” she adds. “You’re on call.”
sections.system: Note: You gained a key tool. (Pager)

choices.label: Take the pager and clip it on
Ask if she’ll cover you if it goes sideways
Joke that you’re flattered she trusts you

sections.text:
Kimberly snorts, but it’s not unkind.

“I won’t cover you,” she says. “I’ll save you. There’s a difference.”

And somehow that feels more intimate than a compliment.
sections.system: Whisper: She’s offering you something real.

choices.label: Tell her you’ll return the favor
Keep it professional—thank her and move on
Ask if she’s ever been burned by trusting someone

sections.text:
You wear competence like armor.

It works.

Until it doesn’t.

The hospital is full of moments where pretending you’re fine becomes the mistake that follows you forever.
sections.system: Omen: Detachment reads as arrogance when pressure rises. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Refocus—work the floor
Reset—ask Kimberly for one honest tip

sections.text:
Avery nods once.

“Excellent is measurable,” they say. “Perfect is performative. The hospital can’t afford performative.”

They slide a form toward you.

“Consent,” Avery says. “Paperwork saves lives, too—just slower.”
sections.system: Note: You gained a Consent Form. (Useful later)

choices.label: Take the consent form and read it now
Pocket it and promise you’ll review it later
Ask Avery what they want from you, personally

sections.text:
“Short version?” Avery says. “Ego. Shortcuts. Secrets.”

They lean closer.

“And the most dangerous secret is the one you call ‘just this once.’”
sections.system: Whisper: Avery just warned you about romance and malpractice in the same sentence.

choices.label: Ask if they’re speaking from experience
Promise you won’t cut corners
Laugh it off—tell them you’re not that kind of intern

sections.text:
Your joke lands… fine.

Not great. Not terrible.

But in a place like this, “fine” is a thin bridge.

People remember who makes them feel safe.

And who makes them feel like a risk.
sections.system: Note: Charm is not a substitute for credibility. (No Rep change—yet.)

choices.label: Switch to professionalism
Try again—something honest this time

sections.text:
The floor hits you like a wave.

A patient is crying. Someone’s shouting. A monitor alarms like it’s trying to escape.

Kimberly gestures with her chin.

“Room 12,” she says. “Chest pain. New onset.”

Dr. Marlowe is already moving.

Your pager sits quiet for now… but not for long.
sections.system: Whisper: Choose fast, but don’t guess.

choices.label: Go with Marlowe to Room 12
Grab the patient chart first
Ask Avery for clearance to pull prior records

sections.text:
Kimberly scans the hallway like she’s reading a storm.

“Chart says one thing,” she murmurs. “People say another. Patients live somewhere in between.”

She tells you what she noticed: a tremor in the patient’s hands, a missed dose, a family member who won’t stop interrupting.

Little facts. Big consequences.
sections.system: Note: Good listening improves your standing. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Thank her and head to Room 12
Ask if she’ll come with you
Ask what Marlowe is like off-shift

sections.text:
Kimberly’s mouth quirks.

“Marlowe?” she says. “Brilliant. Dangerous. Better than she wants to be. Worse than she admits.”

Then Kimberly’s eyes flick toward you.

“And she hates wasting time.”

Somehow that sounds like a warning and a dare.
sections.system: Whisper: Everyone in this building notices who you notice.

choices.label: Go to Room 12 before Marlowe notices you lingering
Ask Kimberly if she’s jealous
Ask Kimberly if she ever wished she could leave

sections.text:
You try to justify the guess.

Marlowe’s eyes sharpen.

“Stop,” she says. Not loud—worse. Final.

In the silence that follows, you feel the floor’s attention swing toward you.

Hospitals are gossip engines with lab coats.
sections.system: Omen: Doubling down costs you standing. (-2 Rep)

choices.label: Apologize and ask to review the chart
Storm off to prove yourself elsewhere

sections.text:
The pager clips onto you like a new heartbeat.

You feel the weight of responsibility.

And then it buzzes.

CODE BLUE — ER BAY 3.

Someone is crashing.

Everyone moves.

This is the part where you become who you are under pressure.
sections.system: Omen: This moment can change your Rep fast—up or down.

choices.label: Run to ER Bay 3 now
Grab Emergency Meds on the way
Find Marlowe first—don’t walk into chaos alone

sections.text:
Kimberly’s expression shifts—just a hair.

“I used to think leaving meant failing,” she says.

“And then I realized staying can be its own kind of failure if you stop feeling anything.”

She looks at you, and for a moment the hospital is just two people in a hallway trying to survive their own hearts.
sections.system: Whisper: This is a bond moment. You’ll feel it later.

choices.label: Tell her she doesn’t have to go numb around you
Keep it gentle—thank her for trusting you
Change the subject—back to work

sections.text:
You skim the consent form.

It’s not romantic.

It’s not dramatic.

But it’s the thin paper barrier between a hard day and a ruined life.

You notice language that matters: capacity, witnesses, documentation.

You pocket it like it’s a weapon made of bureaucracy.
sections.system: Note: Paperwork can prevent malpractice outcomes later.

choices.label: Head back to the floor
Ask Avery about the hospital’s last scandal

sections.text:
Avery’s gaze holds yours.

“I want this place to run clean,” they say. “And I want you to stay clean in it.”

Then, quieter:

“And I want you to remember I’m not your enemy—unless you give me a reason.”
sections.system: Whisper: Avery’s attention can protect you… or end you.

choices.label: Say you’d rather earn their trust than their mercy
Flirt—subtle, risky, electric
Back away—this is too dangerous

sections.text:
Room 12 smells like antiseptic and fear.

The patient—middle-aged, sweating—clutches their chest.

A family member hovers like a storm cloud.

Marlowe speaks fast, calm.

“Vitals. Timeline. Meds.”

Then she looks at you.

“Intern. What’s the first thing you do?”
sections.system: Whisper: This is a competence test. Romance watches from the corner of the room.

choices.label: Ask the patient to describe the pain and onset
Order an EKG and labs immediately
Turn to the family member and set boundaries

sections.text:
You pull the chart close.

Details jump out: medication interactions. An allergy buried in a note. A missed follow-up.

It’s not just information.

It’s leverage against catastrophe.
sections.system: Note: Preparation improves your standing. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Return to Room 12 ready
Ask Kimberly if this patient has a reputation here

sections.text:
Avery doesn’t blink.

“Prior records require justification,” they say. “Give me one.”

Your stomach tightens.

The right words can open doors.

The wrong ones can brand you as a liability.
sections.system: Whisper: Truth opens more doors than panic.

choices.label: Explain the clinical need calmly
Exaggerate to force urgency
Back off and return to the patient

sections.text:
Kimberly’s eyes flash.

“Jealous?” she repeats.

Then she smiles like a scalpel.

“No,” she says. “Just… observant.”

She steps closer.

“And you’re playing with fire in a building full of oxygen.”
sections.system: Omen: Romance overlap increases risk. (No Rep change yet.)

choices.label: Apologize—tell her you didn’t mean to cheapen it
Lean in—tell her you like that she notices
Deflect—back to patients

sections.text:
You stalk away.

It feels powerful for half a second.

Then your pager buzzes again and power means nothing.

The hospital doesn’t care about your pride.

It only cares about outcomes.
sections.system: Omen: Pride costs time. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Run toward the code
Find Kimberly—ask for help instead of drama

sections.text:
ER Bay 3 is a storm.

A patient is unresponsive. The monitor screams.

Marlowe is there, hands already moving.

Kimberly snaps orders like she owns gravity.

You step in—and the room makes space.

Not because you deserve it.

Because they need you to.
sections.system: Omen: This scene can swing Rep by 2–3 points depending on choices.

choices.label: Start compressions immediately
Check airway and call for intubation support
Freeze for one heartbeat—then ask what Marlowe needs

sections.text:
You grab Emergency Meds.

Your fingers shake.

Not fear.

Adrenaline.

You can feel your choices forming consequences in real time.

When you reach the bay, Marlowe’s eyes flick to the meds and back to the patient.

Approval, sharp as a blade.
sections.system: Note: You came prepared. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Hand the meds to Marlowe and wait for direction
Offer the meds and propose a plan (careful)
Give the meds to Kimberly—trust her triage instincts

sections.text:
You find Marlowe in motion.

She doesn’t slow down.

“You’re late,” she says.

Then, without looking at you:

“Don’t be late again.”

It shouldn’t feel like flirting.

It does.
sections.system: Omen: Hesitation under pressure harms your standing. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Follow her into the code and make up for it
Tell her you were securing supplies

sections.text:
You choose honesty.

Kimberly exhales like she was holding tension in her ribs.

“Good,” she says. “Because this place will punish you for being fake.

But it might forgive you for being real.”
sections.system: Note: Repairing trust improves your standing. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Go to the code together
Ask if she’ll meet you for coffee after shift

sections.text:
Avery’s mouth twitches.

“Last scandal?” they repeat. “We don’t call it a scandal. We call it a lesson.”

They lower their voice.

“A patient died. People panicked. Paperwork vanished. Careers vanished.

And the hospital learned what it looks like when truth becomes optional.”
sections.system: Whisper: Avery is warning you about the malpractice ending without saying it.

choices.label: Ask what saved the people who survived it
Promise you won’t hide mistakes
Decide you don’t want to know and walk away

sections.text:
You flirt.

It’s subtle—an edge of a smile, a tone that says you understand the game and still chose to play.

Avery’s gaze doesn’t waver.

“Careful,” they murmur. “I’m not the kind of mistake you recover from.”
sections.system: Omen: Forbidden attraction. High reward, high risk.

choices.label: Back off—keep it professional
Lean in—ask what they mean

sections.text:
You keep your voice calm.

“Tell me where it hurts. When it started. What makes it worse.”

The patient’s breathing steadies.

Even the family member pauses.

Marlowe watches you like she’s watching a fire catch.
sections.system: Note: Patient-centered care improves Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Proceed with EKG and labs
Ask Kimberly to pull meds and allergies
Ask Marlowe if she wants you to lead the initial workup

sections.text:
You order the workup.

The machine prints its verdict in jagged lines.

The patient’s face tightens.

The family member starts talking—fast, frantic.

Marlowe glances at you.

“Interpret it,” she says. “Out loud.”
sections.system: Whisper: This is where the Stethoscope and preparation can matter later.

choices.label: Interpret cautiously and ask Marlowe to confirm
Interpret confidently without confirmation
Ask the nurse for the latest vitals before you speak

sections.text:
You turn to the family member.

“I hear you,” you say. “But I need space to help them.”

They bristle.

Then… they step back.

It’s a small miracle.

Marlowe’s eyes soften.

Just slightly.

Like she’s surprised you can do more than medicine.
sections.system: Note: Leadership under stress improves Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Continue the workup
Ask Kimberly to keep the family updated

sections.text:
Kimberly moves like competence made human.

“Allergies: penicillin,” she says. “Meds: beta blocker. Missed dose yesterday.”

She looks at you.

“Don’t get cute with it,” she adds. “Just get it right.”
sections.system: Whisper: Kimberly’s care is a blade—protective and sharp.

choices.label: Adjust your plan based on the allergy and missed dose
Ignore the detail—stick to your original plan
Ask Kimberly to stay with you for the next step

sections.text:
You explain the clinical need.

Avery watches, then taps a key.

“Approved,” they say.

The door opens.

You just learned something important:

In this hospital, the truth can be a key.

If you carry it cleanly.
sections.system: Note: You earned trust with administration. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Return to patient care with the records
Ask Avery why they helped you

sections.text:
You exaggerate.

Avery’s eyes narrow.

They approve access anyway.

But you feel it—the invisible ink of a note being written next to your name.

Not punitive.

Just… recorded.
sections.system: Omen: Administration notices exaggeration. (-2 Rep)

choices.label: Return to patient care and do better
Try to repair it—admit you overstated urgency

sections.text:
You lean into the heat.

Kimberly doesn’t move away.

For one breath, the hospital fades.

Then the intercom crackles.

Your pager buzzes.

Reality returns like a slap.
sections.system: Omen: Romance overlap increases gossip risk. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Step back and head to the code
Ask Kimberly to meet you after shift—somewhere quiet

sections.text:
You start compressions.

Your arms burn.

You count.

You breathe.

The world becomes rhythm.

Marlowe’s voice slices through the noise:

“Good. Keep going.”

The patient’s monitor flickers.

Not hope.

Not yet.

But possibility.
sections.system: Note: Strong response improves Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Continue compressions until relieved
Ask Kimberly to prep Emergency Meds if available
Make eye contact with Marlowe—silent question: am I doing this right?

sections.text:
You check airway and call for support.

Someone moves in.

It’s the right call.

But the delay costs time.

The monitor dips.

A moment where everyone feels the cliff edge.
sections.system: Omen: Right choices can still have consequences. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Pivot—start compressions now
Call for Emergency Meds and coordinate

sections.text:
You freeze for one heartbeat.

Then you choose humility.

“What do you need?” you ask.

Marlowe’s eyes lock onto yours.

And for the first time today, she sounds… almost kind.

“Follow my voice,” she says. “And don’t break.”
sections.system: Note: Asking for direction prevents a bigger failure. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Start compressions immediately
Assist Kimberly—support the team flow

sections.text:
You offer a plan.

Marlowe’s expression doesn’t change.

But Kimberly’s eyes widen like she’s watching you step into traffic.

Marlowe says, very softly:

“Propose. Don’t presume.”
sections.system: Omen: Overconfidence in a code hurts your standing. (-2 Rep)

choices.label: Correct yourself—ask for confirmation and proceed
Double down anyway

sections.text:
You hand the meds to Kimberly.

She nods—quick, fierce.

“Good call,” she says.

And that approval hits like sunlight.

The team moves as one.

The patient’s monitor steadies.

Not saved.

But not lost yet.
sections.system: Note: Trusting the right person improves Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Stay on task—keep the code running
Ask Kimberly after—quietly—if she’s okay

sections.text:
“After shift,” you say.

Kimberly’s eyes flicker.

“You don’t even know me,” she replies.

But she doesn’t say no.

Instead she says:

“Survive the shift first.”
sections.system: Whisper: Romance promises are earned under pressure.

choices.label: Smile and return to work
Let it go—keep it professional

sections.text:
“Documentation,” Avery says. “Witnesses. Consent.

And one person willing to say, out loud, ‘This is what happened.’”

They pause.

“Truth isn’t dramatic,” they add.

“It’s just expensive.”
sections.system: Whisper: This is the path to a whistleblower special ending.

choices.label: Ask for an Incident Report Folder
Promise you’ll document everything
Decide you want no part of politics

sections.text:
Avery watches you like you’re a headline waiting to happen.

“Because interns,” they say, “are either trainwrecks… or miracles.

And I prefer to invest in miracles.”

Their voice dips.

“Don’t make me regret it.”
sections.system: Omen: Avery’s interest is protective—until it isn’t.

choices.label: Ask what they’d consider ‘regret’
Thank them and return to the floor

sections.text:
Marlowe studies you.

“Lead,” she says.

It feels like permission.

And also like a trap.

You step into the role.

The patient watches you like you’re the difference between fear and relief.
sections.system: Omen: Leadership magnifies both success and failure.

choices.label: Use the chart detail and proceed carefully
Push fast—speed over caution

sections.text:
You slow down just enough to be right.

You adjust the plan. You avoid the allergy. You keep the patient calm.

Marlowe’s gaze lingers.

Kimberly’s shoulders drop by a fraction.

You feel it: the hospital rewarding you for doing the unglamorous thing.

Correct.
sections.system: Note: Excellent care improves Rep. (+2 Rep)

choices.label: Transition to the next crisis—your pager is already buzzing
Stay a moment and speak gently to the family member

sections.text:
You interpret confidently.

The room shifts.

Marlowe’s voice cuts in.

“That’s not correct.”

Not cruel.

But devastating.

The patient’s family member hears it.

So does the nurse.

So does the entire invisible web of reputation you didn’t even know was listening.
sections.system: Omen: A public mistake harms Rep. (-2 Rep)

choices.label: Own it immediately and correct course
Blame the machine or the nurse (bad idea)

sections.text:
You move fast.

Too fast.

The patient’s face tightens.

Kimberly’s voice snaps:

“Allergy!”

You stop just in time.

Not a disaster.

But close enough that the room will remember you as ‘almost.’
sections.system: Omen: Near-miss damages Rep. (-1 Rep)

choices.label: Thank Kimberly and adjust plan
Act offended—make it about ego

sections.text:
You return to Avery.

“I overstated it,” you admit. “I was scared.

But I’m asking the right way now.”

Avery stares for a long moment.

Then nods.

“Good,” they say. “That’s how you recover.”
sections.system: Note: Accountability restores Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Return to the floor with records
Ask Avery if they ever forgive people

sections.text:
The code stabilizes.

Not saved forever.

But alive.

Breathing.

Someone in the room exhales like they were holding their soul in their lungs.

Marlowe looks at you.

“Good work,” she says.

It sounds like praise.

It also sounds like an invitation.
sections.system: Note: You gained serious credibility. (+2 Rep)

choices.label: Follow Marlowe into the hallway—debrief alone
Check on Kimberly—she carried half the weight
Report the event cleanly using paperwork if you have it

sections.text:
You coordinate.

Not flashy.

Not heroic.

Just competent.

And in medicine, competence is a kind of romance—because it means people live.

Kimberly glances at you.

Marlowe notices.

Avery, somewhere behind glass, notices too.
sections.system: Note: Teamwork improves Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Stay with the team and finish the code
Slip out and document everything while memories are fresh

sections.text:
In the hallway, Marlowe’s mask cracks—just a little.

“You did well,” she says again.

Then quieter:

“Don’t make me regret caring.”

The word caring lands like a confession.

You realize you want her approval the way some people want oxygen.
sections.system: Omen: Marlowe romance is high intensity. It can raise you—or scorch you.

choices.label: Say you want her guidance—and her respect
Flirt back—dangerous and bold
Keep it professional—thank her and step away

sections.text:
Everything goes wrong at once.

A raised voice.

A wrong assumption.

A witness you didn’t notice.

A note written in invisible ink beside your name.

The patient outcome becomes a question.

And the hospital answers questions with investigations.

A security officer meets you outside the bay.

“Intern,” they say. “We need to talk.”
sections.system: Omen: BAD ENDING — Malpractice / arrest path triggered.

choices.label: Bad Ending: Medical Malpractice Arrest
Return To Main Menu

sections.text:
Kimberly’s hands are steady, but her eyes aren’t.

“Codes don’t scare me,” she says.

“What scares me is what people do after.”

She looks at you like she’s asking a question with no safe answer.

Are you worth the risk?
sections.system: Whisper: Kimberly romance is tenderness under pressure—until gossip breaks it.

choices.label: Tell her she matters to you—no jokes
Keep it professional and thank her
Confess you’re also drawn to Marlowe (messy)

sections.text:
You open the folder.

You document.

You timestamp.

You list witnesses.

It’s not cinematic.

But it’s power.

Avery appears like they were summoned by the smell of paperwork.

“Good,” they say softly. “That’s how you survive the machine.”
sections.system: Note: Truth-first documentation improves Rep. (+1 Rep)

choices.label: Ask Avery what this protects you from
Return to the floor and keep working

sections.text:
Avery’s voice is quiet.

“From scapegoating,” they say. “From panic. From politics.”

They look at you like you’re a secret they shouldn’t want.

“If you keep your hands clean,” they add, “you’ll go far here.”

Then, almost a whisper:

“And if you don’t… I’ll be the one who signs the paperwork that ends you.”
sections.system: Omen: Avery romance is forbidden heat with real consequences.

choices.label: Special Ending: Whistleblower Protection (Avery)
Step back—this is too dangerous

sections.text:
Night settles over the hospital like a blanket that doesn’t warm.

You check your badge.

Your pager.

Your hands.

Your heart.

You’re still standing.

In a place that tries to turn people into machines.

And three people—Marlowe, Kimberly, Avery—have all noticed you.

Not the way interns get noticed.

The way trouble gets noticed.

The way possibility gets noticed.
sections.system: Note: Demo complete. Your choices shaped your Rep and romance threads.

choices.label: Good Ending: Promotion & Clean Record
Special Ending: Forbidden Romance Scandal
Special Ending: Burnout Escape
Return To Main Menu

sections.text:
A statement is taken.

Your badge is clipped off your scrubs like a piece of your identity being removed.

A nurse avoids your eyes.

Someone whispers your name the way people whisper a warning.

You realize the hospital doesn’t hate you.

It just can’t afford you.

And that’s worse.
sections.system: BAD ENDING: Arrest / malpractice outcome. The hospital protects itself first.

choices.label: Return To Main Menu

sections.text:
Marlowe signs your evaluation.

Kimberly nods at you like you earned her trust.

Avery’s email arrives five minutes later.

Recommendation. Advancement. A future.

You didn’t just survive.

You proved you belong.

And in a building full of oxygen, you learned to carry fire without burning the place down.
sections.system: GOOD ENDING: High standing, clean record, promotion path unlocked.

choices.label: Return To Main Menu

sections.text:
You choose documentation over drama.

Truth over charm.

And Avery—dangerous, brilliant Avery—chooses to protect you.

Not because they’re soft.

Because they’re strategic.

The hospital machine turns.

But you don’t get crushed under it.

You learn how to stand beside it.

And quietly, you learn how to be wanted by someone who could end you with a signature.
sections.system: SPECIAL ENDING: Whistleblower shield / Administration alliance.

choices.label: Return To Main Menu

sections.text:
Someone sees a lingering look.

A touch that lasts too long.

A closed door.

A rumor grows like mold.

It doesn’t ruin you.

Not yet.

But it stains your name.

And in a hospital, a stain is a story people repeat.

You survive.

But you learn the price of being messy in a place that punishes mess.

sections.text:
You stare at the lockers after shift.

The fluorescent lights hum like a warning.

You think about the code.

The almost-mistake.

The way your heart tries to become a machine just to keep up.

You choose yourself.

Not failure.

Not weakness.

A different kind of survival.

You leave the hospital alive.

And you don’t come back tomorrow.
sections.system: SPECIAL ENDING: Burnout exit. You save yourself, but the story ends early.
